@Everyday Astronaut: I hope you also take some lessons from this.. when you are doing a live stream of a rocket launch, while you're explaining things, please keep looking at the screen rather than at the camera, so you don't miss something that everyone that payed attention had already noticed. Having said this: I also don't understand that the presenter from Rocket Lab at 37:32 is reading out the telemetry as if nothing happened, while the rocket has already been without thrust for almost a minute ans has dropped several kilometers in altitude, and at 38:26 he even says "However, we are continuing to receive GOOD telemetry from Electron". How is that telemetry good? At that point we're at almost 2 minutes without thrust and losing altitude for over a minute. At 42:08 he just ends the webcast without any acknowledgement that something went wrong? Bizarre.. Also, at 32:28 "coming up at 30 km/h, almost 10 miles in altitude, for those of us metrically impaired". This apparently includes you Tim, as 30 km is 18,6 miles. :-)

metric makes more sense as we count numbers in 10, 100, 1000, etc and likewise when we look at things in decrement of 1/10, 1/100, etc. However, for inch, feet, miles it is like inch to feet it is 12, and converting feet to miles is 5280. It is very hard to visualise linearly as the scale of measurement increases and when you go down in size, metric is much much easier than using imperial.

man i forgot to watch the stream

This is one time when Tim was doing his job at explaining so well that he didn't notice the telemetry, which clearly showed the rocket stop accelerating as it approached hotswap. At this point in the mission, the rocket was so near apogee that it soon stopped decelerating and began accelerating due to altitude loss. This happened quickly enough that Tim missed it during the Live feed. The "good" telemetry was NOT good; late second-stage engine acceleration looks nothing like the acceleration we were seeing before the telemetry disappeared.

It's really unfortunate that they took the telemety away from the stream.
I really like that they are upfront on what happened and posted an article to their own website and not tried to cover things up. I wish other companies have that kind of transparency.

Or is the battery weight not significant enough to warrant investment in non-off the shelf battery ?

Hi Tim, It should be noted that both Virgin Galactic and Blue Origin rely on the spacecraft still going up when he engines cut off. Basically, you get weighlessness from MECO to apogee (somewhere around the Karman line) and back down until the atmosphere bites. You're freefalling upwards at first as paradoxical as it sounds. m/s * 2.25 = ~mph. As a first order approximation, m/s=mph, but it's hideous. The UK govt has some notion it can maybe do GPS on the cheap with Oneweb. It's needed because out of the EU, we are not guaranteed GPS access by either the US or the EU. It's not really bothered about competing with Starlink. The UK has loads of blackspots for internet coverage so they'd like to plug that gap as well.
